title: Artificial Gravity Attenuates the Transcriptomic Response to Spaceflight in the Optic Nerve and Retina
background: Spaceflight-associated neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS) is a serious concern for astronauts during deep space missions, characterized by physiological and pathological neuro-ophthalmic abnormalities including optic disc edema, globe flattening, and retinal changes.
objective: Evaluate whether artificial gravity (AG) could mitigate the deleterious effects of microgravity on the retina and optic nerve during spaceflight, and compare the effectiveness of different AG levels (0.33 G, 0.67 G, 1 G).
methods: RNA sequencing of optic nerve and retinal tissue from mice exposed to microgravity (0 G) or artificial gravity (0.33 G, 0.67 G, 1 G) during a 30-day International Space Station mission, with habitat ground controls. Immunofluorescence for oxidative stress biomarker 4-HNE.
results: Spaceflight induced transcriptomic changes consistent with increased oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid metabolic stress. Artificial gravity attenuated these changes in a dose-dependent manner, with 1 G providing the strongest attenuation. 4-HNE staining confirmed oxidative stress reduction at 0.67 G and 1 G.
conclusion: Adding artificial gravity by centrifugation on board the ISS, especially near 1 G, can significantly reduce transcriptomic alteration induced by spaceflight in ocular tissue, potentially mitigating spaceflight-induced detrimental effects.

learning_notes.note: Spaceflight induces significant transcriptomic changes in both optic nerve (206 DEGs) and retina (285 DEGs), with only 28 genes overlapping between tissues, indicating tissue-specific responses to microgravity. Key pathways affected include FoxO signaling, PI3k-Akt signaling, and p53 signaling, all associated with oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis.

Artificial gravity provided through centrifugation (0.33 G, 0.67 G, 1 G) attenuated spaceflight-induced transcriptomic changes in a dose-dependent manner, with 1 G providing the strongest protection. Gene expression patterns progressively reverted toward ground control levels as artificial gravity increased from 0 G to 1 G.

The oxidative stress biomarker 4-HNE showed significantly increased immunoreactivity in the retinal ganglion cell layer under microgravity (0 G) and low artificial gravity (0.33 G), but levels were indistinguishable from ground controls at 0.67 G and 1 G artificial gravity, confirming functional protection against oxidative damage.

Pathway analysis revealed p53 signaling was significantly enriched in both optic nerve and retina during spaceflight, with genes in this pathway showing progressive attenuation with increasing artificial gravity. p53 activation is linked to oxidative stress-induced DNA damage response and apoptosis.

The study used JAXA's Centrifuge-Equipped Biological Experiment Facility on the ISS with rotation rates of 44 rpm, 63 rpm, and 77 rpm to generate 0.33 G, 0.67 G, and 1 G artificial gravity respectively during a 30-day mission, demonstrating the feasibility of in-flight centrifugation for gravitational countermeasures.

Transcriptomic responses to spaceflight showed substantial overlap with published models of optic nerve crush and glaucoma, suggesting common pathological mechanisms between spaceflight-induced ocular changes and terrestrial ocular diseases involving neurodegeneration and oxidative stress.

The study identified that 0.67 G of artificial gravity was sufficient to normalize both transcriptomic changes and oxidative stress biomarkers to ground control levels, suggesting that full Earth gravity (1 G) may not be necessary for effective ocular protection during spaceflight.
